intro: Lappula echinata f. cupulata, commonly known as the cupulate lappula, is a herbaceous plant characterized by its distinctive cup-like structure on its bracts. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is native to arid and semi-arid regions of Europe and western Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine hairs. Its leaves are lanceolate and often have a bluish-green hue, while the flowers are small and clustered in dense, spike-like inflorescences. This variant is notable for its unique morphological features, which distinguish it from other forms of Lappula echinata.
